author: Daniel Johnson
title: Russian Grand Prix practice descends into farce
text:
Russian Grand Prix practice descends into farce Oil spills and atrocious weather render first day of practice pointless in Sochi Spray flies up behind Fernando Alonso's McLaren in Sochi Photo: REUTERS By Daniel Johnson , Formula One Correspondent , Sochi 1:46PM BST 09 Oct 2015 Comments 
This has to be a contender for one of the most pointless days of practice in Formula One’s history. 
The first session was blighted by a farcical oil spill caused by blundering circuit officials, and the second was a total washout, with the Sochi track still precariously slippery. 
The window for dry running came in the morning, but it soon became clear first practice would be a shambles. The Sochi Autodrom tweeted their excitement at the action ahead, but running was delayed by half an hour as marshals desperately tried to clean up the diesel spill. 
The scene is set in Sochi 
It seems a truck employed to clean the track had been dumping oil out of the back. Then, even more inexplicably, marshals tried cleaning the spill with water, only making matters worse. 
After tiptoeing around, Sebastian Vettel summed it up when he said over team radio: “What a mess.” 
• Button explains his retirement u-turn 
The drivers had to go out onto a dry track on intermediate and wet tyres because the area around turn eight was so treacherous. They had to almost back off completely to try and negotiate the spill. 
It allowed McLaren to top the times for a while, but no truly competitive laps could be posted. Nico Hulkenberg ended fastest in his Force India but it was a meaningless accolade. 
Mercedes' Nico Rosberg struggles in the wet 
Sergey Vorobyev, the race promoter in Sochi, said: "All the practice sessions are running according to schedule, so the incident is not critical. 
"There was a diesel spill and it took us some time to clean it - which caused the delay. So there will be an investigation and it is an internal matter now." 
Second practice was even worse. It began with rain and clouds which almost brought darkness to the Sochi Autodrom. The area around the spillage was even more hazardous than the rest of the track. 
With 20 minutes remaining, only three drivers had bothered to set a lap time. Felipe Massa ended the session fastest. 
The teams will be hoping for some dry running on Saturday morning – and a clean track – to make up for lost time.
